Definition: In this task, you are given a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to classify the comment into two classes: obscene and non-obscene. Obscenity refers to materials and acts of pornography that are offensive to the public sense of decency.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Damn!  Another cloudy day, and it's all Obama's doing!
Positive Examples.explanation: This is obscenity because it hints on sexual content that is offensive to the public sense of decency.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Be a victim or shoot back.
Positive Examples.explanation: This is unrelated to pornography or obscenity.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: dbsb, Trump could have condemned white supremacists and Nazis the way he did today (only say it like he meant it rather than like he was a hostage forced to read a statement) AND at the same time condemned the violence. They're not mutually exclusive. The fact he didn't for three days speaks volumes about his own personal beliefs.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment might be considered toxic or racism, but is not obscene.
This comment should be considered obscene because it contains explicit language of obscenity.

Comment: Who gives a crap where the word originated. I spoke about definition, not etymology. 

It's utterly irrelevant where it originated or what it meant when it was created. What matters is what it means today, what people understand when they hear it. Not what it meant once upon a time.

The word "proves"used to mean "to test and show to be false", giving English the expression "the exception that proves the rule" - which literally meant "the exception that shows the rule isn't actually a rule and is not really true".

Over time "proves" lost the meaning of "to show the falsehood of" and only the meaning of "to show it's true" remained, and the proverb survives even though it's modern day meaning makes no sense. It's a kind of bizarre claim that the the rule is true BECAUSE there are exceptions to it.

Words change their meanings over time - and if you don't know the current meaning, you cannot communicate honestly, logically or usefully.

Comment: Motley is right here.  And the judge gave an instruction to the jury to the effect that " the testimony of a single witness who you believe is sufficient to prove any fact in dispute" and therefore to convict.  In sex abuse cases, as the prosecutor, I would ask potential jurors if they could go along with that because in cases of sex crimes, they almost always take place in private; there are no witnesses and the prosecution will only have the victim as the key witness.  So if you think it should take two or more witnesses to convict you would never get convictions in a lot of sexual abuse cases.  Juries can usually tell correctly who is telling the truth.  Yes they could get it wrong but that is how our system works.  Juries decide, not judges or lawyers.

Comment: The very same reason that trap & kill fails is the very same reason that TNR fails. You just cannot trap them faster than they breed, are dumped by criminally irresponsible pet-owners, or as fast as they out-adapt to any trapping method ever invented by man. ANY method dependent on trapping is doomed to fail before you even start. But hunted-to-extinction most certainly works. It even worked on something as small and prolific as The Rocky Mountain Locust that used to darken they skies of half of N. America at one time. A simple 50-cent per bushel bounty on them made them no more. It'll work even better and far faster on targets far larger and breed even far slower -- like COMMUNITY-VERMIN cats.

p.s. If you treat your pet like a 100% expendable bit of litter that can be ran-over by any car, then so too will everyone else treat it that way. The only person to blame for the deaths of ANY of your own animals is YOURSELF. You need to be convicted of animal neglect & endangerment laws.

Comment: North Korea's political-military leadership has been characterized as paranoid, and I agree with that.  Both Koreas are heavily militarized, primarily because either one suspects the other of invasion and political assimilation.  The DMZ is very heavily armed with conventional weapons on both sides.  North Korea has threatened the South with a firestorm of Seoul, which is about 30 miles from the North's artillery, probably just out of range.  So that threat has been debunked.  I believe the North realizes this and with nukes on IRBM's, wants to develop a credible deterrent to an invasion by the South.  Would the North use them?  They would be suicidal to do so, and I believe the North wants primarily to shore up the stalemate between the two governments.  China perhaps sees this as mostly a show of force.  

Any embargo would hurt only the everyday Koreans, who in past hard times have eaten grass soup to survive, while thousands starved to death.  The North's leaders would be unswayed.

Comment: Thank you, Mr Nordlund, for this important column. I note that you actually understate the history of this despicable practice. It wasn't merely the banks denying loans to minorities going back throughout history, but it was the stated policy of the United States government to do so. The creation of the Federal Housing Administration in the 1930s was designed to help white homeowners only. The regulations used a color-coded system for different "grades" of neighborhoods, and blacks and other minorities were explicitly prohibited from getting mortgages for those grades supposedly above their station. The practice ostensibly ended with housing reforms in the 1960s, but, as this column demonstrates, it still continues off the books. This is the dictionary definition of institutional discrimination, and we suffer from its legacy, all of us, to the present day.

Comment: That's a cop-out and an excuse for ignoring the speed limit. Every vehicle I've been in in the past decade, foreign, domestic, passenger car, pick up truck, has read anywhere from 2-3 mph BELOW actual speed (when compared to a GPS unit). Manufacturers design them that way. The only way your speedometer would be so incorrect so as to lead you to believe you were going slower than you were (and thereby unknowingly break the law) is if A.) you installed tires larger in diameter than stock or B.) you fail to maintain your vehicle. In either case, it's your own fault. And in the case of larger tires, you can have your speedometer recalibrated.

I can only suggest that as someone who has owned  several rental units over the years, that the forced savings  of owning real estate is superior to whatever he thinks people will do with their money.  All fixed costs are rolled into rent, so if you think you are not paying for my maintenance, building insurance and taxes, you are mistaken, plus most rental occupants  have content insurance.  When the home is paid for, your fixed costs greatly reduce, where the renter continues to pay yearly rent increases for life.  In my experience of owning rental units for over 30 years I know of a small percentage of occupants who invest beyond there rent, because many renters like the freedom and no responsibility of maintaning a home, and use the money for travel and entertainment much more that the homeowner. In addition your primary residence's appreciation is tax free, so it is almost an additional tfsa.

Comment: Many Asian women did indeed provide “comfort” services to the Japanese Imperial Forces during World War II, but I do not believe they did it at the point of a gun nor was it sexual slavery.    Throughout history, military forces have had no problem finding “comfort women” regardless of the country in which they operated and they were able to find them without kidnapping, coercion or threats of any kind.  Wars create horrible conditions which cause people to resort to often unthinkable means to survive.  For many women, it was the use of their bodies, and there usually was more supply than demand.  I personally witness this during the Korean War and during two years in Vietnam.  Some members of the Imperial Japanese forces no doubt forced women to have sex, which, of course, is rape, but I believe the “comfort women” who served the Imperial Japanese forces in brothels that sprung up and operated near Japanese bases did so voluntarily for pay.

Comment: The media pushes the feel good.  The root cause of America's mass murders lies far deeper than gun purchases.  America is a society that foster's labeling of citizens as valuable or not valuable.  Felons are ostracized for life without a second thought.  People are thrown away in life sentences for offenses less than premeditated murder.  People are placed on sex offender lists for life without recourse.  The prison actions simply reflect the American view that there are good people and bad people and that the latter can be discarded without consequence, care, or compassion.  Trouble is, we teach that respect for life is not universal and thus each individual can frame groups that do not matter and kill them.  The only way to really end the killing is to teach universal respect for our fellows.  Things like prison remain necessary when reform fails, but the routine dumping of life as having no value, is a great teacher, and we pay dearly in terms of consequence.

He has no proposal to replace it and apparently no intention to replace it, but with the cooperation of a Republican congress, he may repeal it. Comment: the primary cause of crisis was Frank and Dodd's push to reduce mortgage buying standards at Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, who provide liquidity to mortgagees by buying the loans they (the mortgagees) make to the public. Before Frank and Dodd were able to pass legislation weakening Fannie and Freddie's buying standards, all mortgages purchased off the primary market by these two Government Sponsored Enterprises adhered to Federal Housing Administration standards, i.e. they were "prime" loans. But Frank, Dodd, and their cohorts "rolled the dice" in regards to subprime lending, and, in effect, drowned Fannie and Freddie with junk mortgage paper. In turn, Fannie and Freddie sold the junk loans to institutional investors, who happily bought them with cheap capital provided by the Fed. Attaching trillions of dollars of derivatives to the junk they bought, these investors (particularly the Big Banks) created a bona fide financial crisis.

Comment: http://atforum.com/2013/02/buprenorphine-vs-methadone/
You should educate yourself about it, I have. I can list dozens of sites of information on it.
I am NOT saying it is the quick fix, Suboxone, but when compared to methadone and Vivitrol, it seems to be a better alternative. The best course of treatment is to use it and drug treatment(one on one counseling and group counseling) which can all be out patient.
By the way, suboxone is covered by Medicaid and most private insurances.
Combine it with trained medical people to administer and monitor.
Vivitrol has been more on the rise by jails because it is injected. It has had some success with alcoholics. 
But Suboxone can be misused unless it is given once a day (visiting nurse or at a clinic) until the person is doing well enough to be given prescription.
I think the big Pharma, if smart would offer all the treatment meds but naltrexone for free.
But they won’t be that smart and the greedy sob’s will need to get their fannys sued.

Comment: Mr Chimp, you claim that diversity is in itself meritorious, and that it "strengthens organizations" to "select for diversity," all other things being equal. Comment: Brutalism was and remains ugly, reflecting in its entire oeuvre 
a built manifestation of totalitarian anti human aloofness ... 
the architecture reflecting the zeitgeist existing after 35 years of 
war. Of course, everyone, when Brutalusm was in vogue was far more 
conscious of living under the threat of a final global conflagration. Not surprisingly the Berlin Wall and fall out shelters are reflected in the architecture. 

Communism, as well, was popular among idealists at the time ... cool and
aloof. Brutalism must have emerged from the collective pessimism of those
whom had witnessed the war in their formative years. Brutalism was, and is
dark, brooding and pessimistic.

Comment: Equality is about exactly that: Treating everyone equally. That includes those who are perceived to be in positions of power, and those who are perceived to be at the bottom of the ladder. 

Equality is a meaningless concept if the same rules do not apply to both. There can never be equality in any meaningful sense for as long as one set of rules counts for people x and another set of rules counts for people y, because power relations. 

It's a mockery of justice and an indictment of our legal system if this pseudo-intellectualism has crept into our legal corridors. 

And hate speech is clearly defined in our constitution. Saying 'fuck x people' is not hate speech, regardless of which group you substitute for x.

Comment: As I watched 9 more pre-orders roll in today, I had to think, darn, that's 9 more traction non-indicators for Steve.

Your opinion that pre-orders aren't a viable traction indicator is, frankly, nonsense. We clearly articulate preorders as "strong leads" in our offering circular. They are-- anyone who's put cash down, refundable or not, is a much stronger lead than someone who merely signs up for a test drive. Yes, we still have to build a compelling product, and continue to communicate that product to our pre-order customers. While some will certainly fall off, to me it seems likely they will more than be made up for from folks who are unwilling to place a preorder on something that is not yet in production, which is a very common refrain we hear.

Anyway, thanks for the positive home-town encouragement. Means a lot!

Comment: Stupidity problem?  Phil, this is  NOT "Lorane Hwy", which runs from Eugene to Territorial Highway--this is  Territorial Hwy  itself near the community of Lorane.  The project is long overdue, as Territorial is a dangerous, curvy narrow mix of trucks, ag equipment,  cars from tourists and locals, and of course  bicycles.
Long before 99 or I-5 were built it was the major north-south road out of the South Willamette Valley and it's becoming busier again.    In spite of its problems, for those heading towards Roseburg from the Veneta area or coming from the west, it's much faster and shorter  to drive south on historic Territorial  than driving in to Eugene then taking the freeway.        
A recent rebuilding of the bridge over the Siuslaw River took one problem from Territorial, and this planned project  to correct a  curvy area near the ridge which divides the Willamette Valley from the Siuslaw Valley   is another important step to making this beautiful drive safer and more useful.

Comment: I don't think the present POTUS is good for the American brand, but it would be extremely naive think that that is translating into a boon for Canada.

James Carville's "it's the economy, stupid." holds true.

This article rightly cites the struggles outlined in the Naylor report as a barrier to recruitment/retention in science. What's not noted is the fact that places like Vancouver have a cost of living that exceeds Silicon Valley while also having, say, Indianapolis-level opportunities (Toronto's situation seems better, though perhaps not to a degree that tips many towards moving there).

If you're in Canada and you work in some medical/STEM fields cited in this article, the consideration in moving to the US is partly about potentially over 7 figures in earnings/savings over your career. Comment: I disagree.  That's the usual narrative, but it isn't always the case.  There are great public schools, and also awful ones.  There are great Catholic schools, but also awful ones.  Bullying goes on everywhere -- in any kind of school.  It is a societal problem that no one wants to deal with.  

Because of my own, personal, experience in Catholic schools, I told my husband that -- should we decide to have children -- Catholic or other faith-based schools would not be an option for any reason.  His experience was, however, very different from mine.

The reason many Catholic schools take in non-Catholics is to boost the numbers and ensure they are not closed.  I don't doubt many of the children get a quality education, but (at the end of the day) my tax dollars will be being used to prop up a school the purpose of which is to educate one religious group.  I would personally like to see excellent public schools, and small numbers of faith-based schools serving their communities alone.

Comment: In the mid- to late 1930s France had the largest and most powerful army in the world, yet they failed to act against the fledgling German army when it violated the Versailles treaty and occupied the Rhineland. The French could have easily defeated the Germans, and removed Hitler from power, but they didn't - they sat back and watched as the Germans grew stronger, and before long, it was too late. 

Today, the US and its allies sit back and watch Kim develop nuclear-tipped ICBMs. And, they do nothing. Very, very soon, it will be too late.

Each experiment brings the North Koreans one step closer to their goal of building nuclear-tipped ICBMs that will reach North America. Once that happens,  it is a matter of when - not if - but when a nuclear missile from North Korea flattens a city in Japan, South Korea, the US or Canada. Make no mistake, it will absolutely, certainly happen. 

Those who do not learn from history are doomed to repeat it. We, evidently, have not learned a damn thing.

Comment: Interesting to see how and whether these numbers correlate with our own mini-Trump era from 2006 to 2015. In fairness, Harper was nothing close to this clumsy, incoherent, offensive, ethically challenged 'leader of the free-world'. But they shared some basic instincts regarding the relationship between leaders and the societies they were elected to serve. In substance if not degree, they each believe they are above the law and exempt from constitutional constraint. Electoral rules, democratic precedent, watchdog agencies, and other branches of government (particularly supreme courts) are viewed as enemies of the state. One motivated by ideology; the other by avarice. 

Our dalliance with autocratic rule never plumbed the depths of the abyss now enveloping America - in part because Harper was no Trump and in part because it would never have been tolerated by Canadians and Canadian institutions. It remains to be seen whether and for how long it will be tolerated in the United States.

Comment: An Emperor owned a majestic white stallion, the finest beast in all his Kingdom. One night, a thief tried to slip in and steal the horse, but was captured by the palace guards and thrown into the dungeon.
The next morning, he was dragged before the Emperor's court. "How dare you," bellowed the Emperor, "lay hand on my royal steed! Jailor, put this thief to death!" 
Immediately, the thief bowed deeply. "Your judgement is peerless and wise, O Emperor," he calmly replied, "but my life is of little value. I should offer you a gift before I depart. Your mount is quite a fine one, but if your eminence would spare my life for just a year and a day, I swear to you I can teach that horse to sing.  To the surprise of all, the Emperor quickly accepted the offer.
The jailor whispered to the thief, "You are a fool!" You will be tortured when you fail.
" I am a fool?" Much can happen in a year and a day. The King may die. The horse may die. I may die... and maybe the horse will learn how to sing."

Comment: The Constitution does not explain the reasons for its content in depth. For that you have to read the writings of the Founders. Such as these:

The liberty of the press is essential to the security of freedom in a state: it ought not, therefore, to be restrained in this commonwealth.
John Adams, Samuel Adams, James Bowdoin (1780). Constitution of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

If a nation expects to be ignorant and free, in a state of civilization, it expects what never was and never will be. The functionaries of every government have propensities to command at will the liberty and property of their constituents. There is no safe deposit for these but with the people themselves; nor can they be safe with them without information. Where the press is free, and every man able to read, all is safe.
Thomas Jefferson, Letter to Colonel Charles Yancey (6 January 1816) ME 14:384.

Comment: "Truth and facts are not hate speech."

Yet as you pointed out, the truth doesn't belong to you. So what is it, exactly, that you're offering?

What propaganda doesn't do is give ALL the facts, presented in a balanced way. Hate speech does the same thing. It hammers on the faults of a group- which are typically the same ones you can say of any group- over and over. Comment: The 'Star-Spangled Banner'--the original unexpurgated version--includes death-threats to runaway slaves seeking refuge among the British. Logical to conclude it would have a 'special' meaning to many black Americans, past and present.

Similarly the flag, as many have pointed out, can have different connotations to different people. I would argue it stood as a symbol of betrayal and murder to the peaceful Cheyenne and Arapaho elders, women and children who huddled beneath it in their final moments at Sand Creek, Colorado.

I fail to see how the meanings Trent Lott or Newt Gingrich ascribe to the flag are more acceptable than the Cheyennes'. It certainly didn't help them as they sought shelter beneath it, crying for mercy. Nor will it help us to hide behind the flag from the bitter truths of this nation's crimes.

Mark Twain, horrified by US atrocities in the Philippines campaign, remarked the US flag should be redesigned--from the 'Stars and Stripes' to the Skull and Crossbones.

Comment: I am surprised that none of our intrepid reporters/columnists have pointed out something remarkable here.

The L-G rejected her First Minister's advice.  Clark asked for a dissolution.  The L-G dismissed her and called on Horgan to form a government.  This is unheard of in the last 90 years. Think of back in 2009 or around there when the federal Libs, NDP and BQ were all ready to bring Harper down, with Dion as PM.  Harper asked for an unscheduled prorogation, and Michaele Jean gave it to him.  

And, of course, we have the Byng-King affair back in 1926, which basically set the precedent that the Queen's representative in Canada follows the advice of the First Minister. The G-G ignored Mackenzie King in 1926 and called on Arthur Meighen and the Conservatives to form a government.  That one was over almost as quickly as the Clark government after the election in May.  A new election was then called, and Mackenzie King and the Liberals romped to victory, making the G-G look like a fool.

Comment: According to Alceste, this case is about:

"* TWU rules allowed married heterosexual students to have sex together.

* TWU rules do NOT allow same-sex married students to have sex together."

As you can see, TWU's policy has a discriminatory feature. It doesn't treat same-sex married students the same as it treats heterosexual married students. As you can also see, TWU can rectify that discrimination in more than one way. The first way would be to allow same-sex married students to have sex together. However, that would be a total repudiation of TWU's principles and beliefs. The second way would be to ask all students, married or not, to refrain from having sex while attending the university. That would treat all students equally, and hence LSUC's case would immediately fall apart.

Given that TWU is a school of devout Christian believers, if forced to do so which do you think they would choose: To repudiate their beliefs, or to make a temporary sacrifice for them?

Comment: A party of five tourists from Nome, accompanied by an old-timer chef, travel by snowmachines to Fairbanks. During the first day goings-on, the tourist are rude and obnoxious. That evening, the chef includes a handful of moose nuggets to the stew. He asks the tourists, "How's the stew?" Their answer, "Tastes like moose shit!" Just then the chef pulls out a revolver and says, "The next complaint will be met with lead." Along the trail the following day, no rude behavior and all is quiet. That night the chef adds more nuggets to the stew. No complaints. Third night, the chef adds more nuggets. Still, no complaints. Fourth night, just outside Fairbanks, the chef asks, "How's the stew?" The tourists reply, "Tastes like moose shit...but good!"

Comment: It is not unusual that people come to believe that The World will end -- not coincidentally -- at about the same time their own lives will likely end. That is, they're getting older, they're running out of sunrises. Novelists regularly succumb to this notion in their later years, their routinely "dystopian" epics shaking impressionable readers though not necessarily The World. An easy write, coming to your television soon enough. But why would anyone with a knowledge of recent history, and mankind's grotesque cruelties, need literary help in imagining further ones. 
In time, given our selfishness and irresponsibility, we might indeed annihilate ourselves or poison ourselves -- but if you have hopes for the weekend, why not fulfil them. If you have kids, you owe it to them at least. Don't let the good ol' Doomsday Clock keep you indoors on a summery weekend.  
Meanwhile, as the old line goes, "The meek are a long time inheriting the Earth."

Comment: " ... fresh off their meeting with the UN committee in Geneva earlier this week" ...
I am assuming that they (as always) flew First Class ... and stayed in the finest hotels. Geneva is so lovely at this time of the year. 

I wonder if they had lunch with Bono.

In the autumn of 1971 I was standing on a dock in northern Manitoba ... a newly-minted school-teacher attending an orientation session before heading still further north. A young native guy walks out along the dock and joins me at the end. A beautiful evening. Silence. Maybe geese overhead ... 

He speaks ... not to me ... but out ... clearly ... onto the big calm lake.

"There is an old legend from my people. <pause> If a hunter makes a very strong bow ... and goes out onto the land and shoots an arrow straight up into the sky ... <pause again> it will strike a large airplane. And on that airplane there will be at least one Indian going to a conference."

Buddy turned to me, smiled mischievously.

You can't "make-up" this shit.

Comment: No one knows how to gauge te outcome based on the ranked ballot.  But isn't the challenge greater than that?   
Each EDA counts as 100 points and the first candidate to get 16901 points, or more, is the winner.  This means that EDA's with a small number of members carry a lot of weight.  If one candidate has 28% support concentrated in many EDA's with few members, that candidate ha a much better chance than another candidate with 35% support concentrated in a few ridings in the GTA.
This is the same approach the Liberals used to choose Justin Trudeau.  Apparently, he had broad support getting over 80% of the points on the first round.  This time around, it seems like a real crap shoot.

Comment: Silly argument.  The S. Ct. reverses about 70%  of all the cases it chooses to hear, from all the circuits and state supreme courts. The judges on the circuit courts comprise some of the brightest legal minds in the country.  The idea that folks with no education in the area or understanding of some of the complexities of the issues criticize their intellect is laughable.

Comment: Cracked column basalt and a transition forest that goes from oak savannah to rain forest conifer to rain shadow pine to oak savannah to high desert.   The slides will be released by water freezing and expanding,  and then thawing,  and rain lubricating the now loosened rocks.   Freezing is one of the important factors.  And rain on frozen ground can be a flash flood event.

Dead,  burned trees,  rot at the mean annual winter  snow level,  be that one foot   or four or more.  You can actually accurately guess the mean annual winter snow level by the height of the stumps from  blowdown in a burn area.  The real danger over time will be snag toboggans rocketing towards the railroad and freeway.....or the back of your home.  

Salvage log or not (that area is mostly helicopter logging ground),  the dead trees will fall.  The issue is who gets to control the aftermath.  My life experience includes fire watch duties,  and when the afternoon humidity dropped,  trees fell.  Wet rot dried out.
